articles.headline: The Gig Economy Dipped Again in the Fall. But How Bad Was It?
articles.snippet: Uber and Lyft will report financial results this week for a year that upended hopes that the companies would soon turn around big losses.
articles.abstract: Uber and Lyft will report financial results this week for a year that upended hopes that the companies would soon turn around big losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a year turned upside down by the pandemic, Roberto Moreno’s experience as a ride-hailing driver in San Diego reflected the fortunes of the companies for which he drove.

articles.headline: Using Connections to Trump, Dershowitz Became Force in Clemency Grants
articles.snippet: The lawyer Alan M. Dershowitz, who represented the former president in his first impeachment trial, used his access for a wide array of clients as they sought pardons or commutations.
articles.abstract: The lawyer Alan M. Dershowitz, who represented the former president in his first impeachment trial, used his access for a wide array of clients as they sought pardons or commutations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time George Nader pleaded guilty last year to possessing child pornography and sex trafficking a minor, his once strong alliances in President Donald J. Trump’s inner circle had been eroded by his cooperation with the special counsel’s investigation into Mr. Trump’s team and its connections to Russia.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: Elon Musk and Snoop Dogg Push Cryptocurrencies to Record Highs
articles.snippet: Bitcoin and even Dogecoin, which began as a playful experiment, are soaring in value as billionaires, companies and celebrities promote the digital currencies.
articles.abstract: Bitcoin and even Dogecoin, which began as a playful experiment, are soaring in value as billionaires, companies and celebrities promote the digital currencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Bitcoin hit a new high above $47,000 on Monday, shooting up more than 45 percent from the beginning of the year.

articles.headline: Crisis Spurs Congress Toward Big Measures to Lift Families From Poverty
articles.snippet: Lawmakers, including at least one Republican, are focused on providing monthly payments to help families with children make ends meet.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers, including at least one Republican, are focused on providing monthly payments to help families with children make ends meet.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The early weeks of the Biden administration have brought a surge of support, in the White House and across party lines in Congress, for what could be the most ambitious effort in a generation to reduce child poverty.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: Denying Incitement, Trump Impeachment Team Says He Cannot Be Tried
articles.snippet: The lengthy legal brief provided the first extended defense of former President Donald J. Trump’s conduct since the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol. It arrived as senators locked in rules for an exceedingly fast trial.
articles.abstract: The lengthy legal brief provided the first extended defense of former President Donald J. Trump’s conduct since the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol. It arrived as senators locked in rules for an exceedingly fast trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump’s lawyers laid out their first extended impeachment defense on Monday, arguing that holding him responsible for the deadly Jan. 6 Capitol attack was nothing more than “political theater” by Democrats, and that the Senate had no power to sit in judgment of a former president.

articles.headline: ‘Its Own Domestic Army’: How the G.O.P. Allied Itself With Militants
articles.snippet: Actions taken by paramilitary groups in Michigan last year, emboldened by President Donald J. Trump, signaled a profound shift in Republican politics and a national crisis in the making.
articles.abstract: Actions taken by paramilitary groups in Michigan last year, emboldened by President Donald J. Trump, signaled a profound shift in Republican politics and a national crisis in the making.
articles.lead_paragraph: LANSING, Mich. — Dozens of heavily armed militiamen crowded into the Michigan Statehouse last April to protest a stay-at-home order by the Democratic governor to slow the pandemic. Chanting and stomping their feet, they halted legislative business, tried to force their way onto the floor and brandished rifles from the gallery over lawmakers below.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: The Great Firewall Cracked, Briefly. A People Shined Through.
articles.snippet: China’s censors finally blocked Clubhouse, but not before users were able to bypass the caricatures painted by government-controlled media and freely discuss their hopes and fears.
articles.abstract: China’s censors finally blocked Clubhouse, but not before users were able to bypass the caricatures painted by government-controlled media and freely discuss their hopes and fears.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, the Chinese government has prevented its 1.4 billion people from speaking freely online. A digital wall separated them from the rest of the world.

articles.headline: ‘The Death Market’: Oxygen Shortage Leaves Mexicans to Die at Home
articles.snippet: With hospitals overrun, Mexicans fighting the coronavirus at home face a deadly hurdle: a lack of oxygen tanks.
articles.abstract: With hospitals overrun, Mexicans fighting the coronavirus at home face a deadly hurdle: a lack of oxygen tanks.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Children call him begging for oxygen for their parents. Grandparents call gasping for air in the middle of the night. People with no cash offer him their cars instead.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Oscar Lopez
